Wilbur-Ellis has implemented a comprehensive EHS Data Management System on the Enablon® platform which we have branded “Navigator.” Navigator provides improved tracking of incidents, investigations and metrics and improves communication between employees and Management. Supplementing the Navigator-driven investigation, Wilbur-Ellis has trained members of our EHSS staff in TapRoot® Root Cause Analysis

Release Prevention Program as well as Process Safety Management and 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of anhydrous ammonia, the only regulated substance on site. In addition to ASME pressure vessel code, Wilbur-Ellis follows Compressed Gas Association Standard G-2.1 as RAGAGEP.  Process Hazards Analyses are facilitated by third party consultants experienced in the methodology.  
Chemical specific prevention steps implemented at the site include excess flow valves, pressure relief valves, emergency shut off valves with cables that run along the length of the horizontal storage tank for quick access, and ammonia training for personnel.

Five-Year Accident History
There have been no qualifying accidents involving ammonia in the five-year period prior to the completion of this Plan.

Emergency Response Program
Wilbur-Ellis is a non-responding stationary source. Personnel are trained to respond to small ammonia releases (e.g., drips and fugitive emissions) using full face respirators and appropriate PPE.  The site coordinates with the Regent Rural Fire Protection District (fire department) regarding specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. The facility has established emergency evacuation procedures to evacuate the site and notify the appropriate agencies regarding a release. The facility's emergency response program is documented in the facility's Emergency Response Procedures. The emergency procedures contain the following key elements:
1)	Procedures for informing local agencies responsible for responding to accidental releases.
2)	Information on emergency health care.
3)	Emergency response training for employees.
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Wilbur-Ellis is implementing a proprietary comprehensive Safety Management System called Guiding People to Safety (GPS). Key safety elements are established and divided into four discrete steps, which direct the site on continuous improvement. RMP/PSM is one of those key el

The Plan describes procedures implemented by Wilbur-Ellis Company (Wilbur-Ellis) to prevent accidental releases of ammonia that could cause harm to the public and the environment from short-term exposures. The Plan includes an analysis of the potential offsite consequences of an accidental release, a five-year accident history, and a release prevention and emergency response program.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Wilbur-Ellis has implemented release prevention and emergency response procedures to minimize the potential for accidental releases of hazardous materials. Emergency response procedures including evacuation procedures and notification procedures have been implemented by Wilbur-Ellis. In addition, Wilbur-Ellis has developed operating procedures and preventative maintenance activities to reduce the likelihood of accidental releases.
This Plan and the emergency response procedures document the accidental release prevention, safety, and emergency policies in place at Wilbur-Ellis.

Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
Wilbur-Ellis is located at 1803 4th Street Northeast in Hettinger, North Dakota (the facility). Wilbur- Ellis is a retailer of fertilizer in the form of anhydrous ammonia stored under pressure. There is one anhydrous ammonia storage tank located at the facility with a capacity of approximately 30,000 gallons. The anhydrous ammonia is transferred from the storage tank into nurse tanks owned by farmers. There may be a maximum of six 1,450-gallon nurse tanks owned by farmers at the facility at a given time. The contents of the storage tank are sold to the local farming community for use as fertilizer.
The facility is usually unmanned, with the exception of about one month per year, when a full time employee from another Wilbur-Ellis branch is assigned.
